conclusion: Each book (weight 5 N) is split into n equal sub-stacks (A₁…Aₙ, B₁…Bₙ).
Mass of every sub-stack: w = 5 N ⁄ n.
They are put on the table in the order A₁ – B₁ – A₂ – B₂ – … – Aₙ (or Bₙ) so 2n sub-stacks form a single vertical pile.
The table is smooth, therefore only the (2n–1) contact surfaces between A-blocks and B-blocks supply kinetic friction.
We pull the whole book B to the right with a steady speed → the required pulling force F equals the sum of the kinetic-friction forces at all those (2n–1) interfaces.

premise: Count the interfaces from the bottom, k = 1, 2, …, 2n–1. At interface k the blocks above it are nos. (k+1)…2n, i.e. (2n – k) blocks.
conclusion: The normal (compressive) force on interface k is N_k = (number of blocks above) × (weight of each block) = (2n – k) w.

premise: Kinetic friction on interface k: f_k = μ N_k = μ w(2n – k).
conclusion: Friction at one interface is f_k = μ w(2n – k).

premise: Sum over all interfaces: F = Σ_{k=1}^{2n-1} f_k = μ w Σ_{k=1}^{2n-1} (2n – k).
conclusion: Total pulling force is F = μ w Σ_{k=1}^{2n-1} (2n – k).

premise: F = μ w n(2n – 1) and w = 5 N / n.
Trial 1: n = 2, F = 4.5 N. Using F = μ (5 N) (2n – 1).
Check with the other trials: n = 4: Predicted F = 5 × 0.30 × (8 – 1) = 10.5 N.
conclusion: Predicted F matches the experimental data for n = 4.
